botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Fruits are ornamental - not to be eaten. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Pyracantha are evergreen shrubs or small trees, with spiny branches bearing simple leaves and corymbs of small white flowers followed by showy red, orange or yellow berries

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in a fertile, well drained soil in full sun or partial shade. In frost prone or exposed locations protect young plants while they establish.
how_to_grow.propagation: Pyracantha can be easily propagated from semi-ripe or hardwood cuttings, or alternatively from seed. Pyracantha seed requires three months of cold stratification in order to germinate. Cultivars won't usually come true from seed.
how_to_grow.pruning: Pyracantha flowers mainly on shoots produced the previous year, so when pruning try to retain as much two-year-old wood as possible. Wear thick gloves when pruning; as its common name (Firethorn) suggests, Pyracantha bears long and very sharp thorns.
how_to_grow.pests: Generally pest-free although birds may eat berries
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to pyracantha scab and honey fungus
